content.description: Gets a bit harder at the top, but is an easy climb. This is one of the only routes really worth doing out here, besides bouldering.
content.protection: Two bolts at the top to clip into. (TR)
content.location: It is the one in the middle with the highest point.

content.description: Sit-start for the full effect. Use the flat crimps to start and find some side-pulls to step your left through and make that reach. Stand-start to cheat yourself of the fun.
content.location: Start on the right side of the huge red paint splotch and go straight to the top.

content.description: Stand-start and go up and right, staying out of the large crack to your left
content.location: Start on the left side of the big red splotch of paint. Ends in the same place as the right variation. Or go straight up the blank-looking face to challenge yourself.

content.description: This one starts to feel a little high, but is not bad. Challenge yourself to keep your hands in the broken up section of the cracks, or wander to either side for a few better holds.
content.location: in the obvious broken up cracky section near the right side of the wall

climbs.name: Unknown (aka Fearless)
climbs.fa: Todd Stephens and Troy Anderson at night. Circa 1998

content.description: This route has two bolts in the wall but nothing at the top. There are no anchors to toprope this climb. Also, I would have a hard time trusting those bolts so it's almost as easy to call it a highball and bring a couple pads. The big shelf near the top means it's pretty much over anyway, so you don't feel as exposed.
content.protection: Pads and spotters or 2 QDs for sketchy bolts.
content.location: Start directly under the odd looking black bolt hanger, at the end of the word 'FEARLESS' painted on the rock.

content.description:
Keep your hands inside the ride. For some fun crack-style climbing try to keep your hands in the crack and utilize some jams. There are face holds if you need them too.

I climbed this as a tall boulder problem, but I could see getting some trad pieces in the crack as well.
content.protection: Trad assortment or pad and spotters
content.location: In the large crack to the right side of the bolted routes.

content.description: This name came from trying to decide if this was worth the risk of trying to pull that roof and continue up as a boulder problem. Worth it. A fun climb that involves stemming off the sides of the cave to make the reach to a good hold before going over the roof. With a couple pads and spotters this move wouldn't be too scary, and the topout is easier, though highball. A pad inside the cave would probably help.
content.protection: Pads and spotters. This is high, with potential fall danger on the outcrop on the bottom of the cave. Don't attempt it if you're not comfortable with the potential danger
content.location: On the left side of the wall, look for the cave that is an easy scramble to get up to. Start in the cave. Easily walk off either direction from the top.

content.description: Highball, with no protection options unless your good at make traditional anchors, even then the top offers little for placement for a TR. The fact that there is a ledge close to the end feels like it isn't quite so high. You can also use the arete on your right to get easier holds.
content.location: Easy to find as long as the big blue paint splotch stays. Otherwise, start about 25 feet right of the cave

content.description: Start low on crimps and find the pinch on top of the large diamond.
content.location: Far right above the red spatter that looks like blood. Look for the head-sized diamond-shaped protrusion.

content.description: Originally a highball boulder problem, the bolt was later added as well as two bolts at the top. If you can lead this to the first bolt, it's pretty well over at that point - may as well call it a boulder. Easy finish to the chains.
content.protection: Draws for one bolt and two bolt anchors (no chains or rings) or pad and spotters
content.location: Right most bolted line. Walk off either direction from the top.

content.description: This route was originally set up as a highball boulder problem. Now it can be TRed or lead with its one bolt.
content.protection: Draws for one bolt and two rusty chains. Or pad and spotters
content.location: Look for one bolt pretty high up and two rusty chains at the top. Right of the highest point on the rock.
